Expectation1: Look out for each other's safety and well-being
Situation1: One sibling is about to cross the street without looking for oncoming traffic.
Situation2: They travel a long distance to participate in an important religious festival, ensuring they fully engage in all rituals and offerings.
Story: I stood at the edge of the crowded street, the air thick with the scent of marigolds and incense from the festival. My stepbrother, Raj, was beside me, his excitement barely contained as he talked about the temple rituals we’d come so far to attend. I knew how important it was for me, as a Hindu, to participate fully in the ceremonies—my family expected me to show devotion, to be present for every offering and prayer. But as the crowd surged forward, Raj darted ahead, not noticing the cars speeding past. My heart pounded. As his step-sibling, I was supposed to look out for him, to keep him safe, especially since our parents trusted me to watch over him in this unfamiliar city. But if I left the festival line now, I might miss the start of the puja, disappointing my family and disrespecting the rituals. I felt torn, my feet rooted to the spot, caught between the pull of my faith and the responsibility I owed to Raj.
